conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to consider the forces acting on each body and the equilibrium conditions.
Body A is a hemispherical body placed on a rough horizontal ground.
Body B is a hemispherical body placed on a rough horizontal ground.
Body C is a hemispherical body with a smooth outer surface placed between A and B.
All three bodies A, B, and C are in a state of rest, with A and B just touching each other and no force acting between them.
The radii of A, B, and C are all R, and the coefficient of kinetic friction between A, B and the ground is μ=√3/6.
The maximum static friction is considered equal to the sliding friction, and the gravitational acceleration is g.
The force of gravity mg acts downward on Body A.
The force of gravity 2mg acts downward on Body B.
The force of gravity mg acts downward on Body C.
The normal force F acts upward on both A and B.
The frictional force f acts downward on C.

premise: The normal force F must balance the force of gravity mg on Body A.
conclusion: The normal force exerted by the ground on A is mg.

premise: The normal force F must balance the force of gravity 2mg on Body B.
conclusion: The normal force exerted by the ground on B is 2mg.

premise: The frictional force f must balance the force of gravity mg on Body C.
conclusion: The frictional force f is mg.

premise: The normal force F is the sum of the normal forces exerted by the ground on A and B.
The frictional force f is the force of friction between the ground and C, given by the coefficient of kinetic friction μ = √3/6 times the normal force F.
